subject: Art & Design
title: Hick's Law: Too Many Choices Paralyze Users
description: A quick, practical guide to Hick's Law: Too Many Choices Paralyze Users.

hook.text: A jam store offered 24 flavors ‚Äî 3% bought. The next day they offered 6 flavors ‚Äî 30% bought. Fewer options, more sales.

buildup.text: Hick's Law states: the more choices you present, the longer it takes to make a decision.

discovery.text: Decision time increases logarithmically with the number of options. 2√ó choices ‚â† 2√ó decision time, but it grows.

twist.text: Netflix shows thousands of options but curates them into small rows of 5-10. Choice architecture hides complexity.

climax.text: Apple's product line is deliberately tiny: one phone in three sizes. Google's homepage has one search bar.

punchline.text: The best design doesn't add options. It removes the unnecessary ones.

quiz.question: What does Hick's Law predict about user behavior?
